name: Mango Chutney
history: Mango Chutney, a staple in Indian cuisine, has roots dating back centuries. This sweet and tangy condiment is made using mangoes, a fruit native to South Asia. It's a versatile accompaniment to many dishes and reflects the rich culinary diversity of the region.
description: Mango Chutney is a sweet and spicy condiment made from ripe or unripe mangoes, sugar, vinegar, and a variety of spices. It's a perfect blend of flavors and is commonly used as a side with Indian meals or as a spread.

instructions.title: Cook Mangoes
instructions.description: In a saucepan, combine the mangoes, sugar, and apple cider vinegar. Cook over medium heat until the sugar dissolves.

instructions.title: Add Spices and Simmer
instructions.description: Add ginger, garlic, raisins, red chili flakes, cinnamon stick, cloves, and salt. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer until the mixture thickens and becomes syrupy.

instructions.title: Cool and Store
instructions.description: Remove from heat and let the chutney cool. Discard the cinnamon stick and cloves. Transfer the chutney to a jar for storage.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the mango chutney with Indian bread, curries, or as a spread on sandwiches.

tips: Adjust the amount of sugar based on the sweetness of the mangoes.
The chutney thickens as it cools, so don't overcook it.
variations: Add a dash of nutmeg or cardamom for extra flavor.
Include diced onions or bell peppers for added texture.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 2 weeks.
storage.instructions: Store in a clean, airtight jar in the refrigerator.

presentationTips: Serve in a small bowl or jar with a spoon for easy serving.
Garnish with a mint leaf or a sprinkle of sesame seeds for a decorative touch.
